lines.text: [first lines]

From her beginnings on a Navy drawing board, through the months of secret field experiments out on the Western desert, then through the desperate search for new metals with the properties she needed, she was designed to be the nation's greatest weapon of the seas - the atom-powered submarine. Her engines were to be a miracle of speed and power, her sides strong enough to withstand any blow, her armament and fire power of greater force than the worst enemy she might encounter. The mind of man had thought of everything - except that which was beyond his comprehension!
[fade to black, fade in on stormy waters and scroll main titles]
[last lines]
Well, I guess that's it. The sub's been ordered on patrol. We'll be on sea duty for a few months. We'll be seeing you, John.
Soon, I hope.
Will I be seeing you, Leslie?
Do you mean when I get back from Cairo?
I mean, women can change, move away, get married, have families.

Well, there is that possibility; but, uh, A - there isn't time for that to happen to me; B - I can be reached at the school; and C - how would you like to collaborate with me on a book, "How To Catch A Sea Beast"?
[takes Pete's chin, draws herself to him, and kisses him on the lips]
Say, doctor, you were right about this new breed of women!
["The End" title appears beneath trio as he starts this line, and music increases volume accordingly, partially drowning him out. Fade to black as line finishes]
The next time I cruise in these waters I'm going to have torpedoes with warheads on them.
This is a submarine, John. If it can go under water, it can go under ships, too. This is a deep channel. Better run below if you don't wanna get wet.
Doctor, what kind of a sea beast would be that large? And what do you call it so I can stop calling it It?
I have no idea.
Nor have I.
[Prof. Carter pulls an octopus from an aquarium tank]
Here, gentlemen, is your villain.
It would take an enormous number of those to disable a Navy submarine.
lines.character: Naval Asst. Sec. Robert David Chase

lines.text: Or just one of enormous size, Mr. Chase.
Say, you mean to tell me the Navy sent you down here in one of those jets just so you could go fishing?
That's about it.
Do you mind if I make a mental comment upon the nature of women?
Look, Pete, you don't see many women in the Seagoing Navy.
Are you kidding me?

Oh, shoreside women, sure. But there's a whole new breed who feel they're just as smart and just as courageous as men. And they are. They don't like to be overprotected. They don't like to have their initiative taken away from them.

A - you'd want me to miss the opportunity to see this specimen, one that may never come again; B - you'd be making up my mind for me; and C - I not only don't like being pushed around, but you underestimate my ability to help in a crisis.
My sympathies are entirely on her side.
Didn't take me very long to lose that argument, did it?
Thought we had the thing figured out. What happened?
I can't tell you. Instead of being driven off, it attacked.
Maybe it wants to *fight*.
